div1.p: No. 66. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, March 15, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. A Concession granted to the Afro-American Steamship and Mining Company of Boston.
Synopsis. The Liberian Government grants a Concession to a company of colored men of Boston to establish a Steamship, Mining and Railway Company in Grand Bassa County Liberia.
No. 66. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; March 15, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transit herewith, the intelligence, that the Liberian Government, has recently granted a Concession, to a Boston company of colored men; represented here by the recent arrival of our Charles P. Weeks, as agent; known as The Afro-American Steamship and Mining Company, of Boston, conceding to said Company the night to established a Steamship Company to operate between Boston and

and Liberia, to erect whereas, and build ; rail and tram ways; and to carry on a system of Mining opperations, for a period of Fifty gear. The Company, however, is to pay the Liberian Government, a consideration of Ten Thousand Dollars, for there special privileges.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
Inclosure. Liberia Recorder Feb'y 28, 1901.

2 THE LIBERIA RECORDER.
Associate Justice Dossen's speech delivered before His Excellency the President in behalf of the Supreme Court of this Republic at the opening of its Annual Sessions.

Mr. President:--The mighty wheel of time has moved steadily onward and in its revolution, has brought around again the time fixed by the laws of this Republic, for the Annual session of the Supreme Court of Liberia, which we have the distinguished honor to represent.

It is to us a cause for unfeigned thanks to the great Disposer of all things, that this ARM of State, which is the highest expounder of the laws under which we live; the guardian of the civil and religious rights and liberties of this people and the source from whence flows a pure, unpolluted stream of Justice and Equity, has been preserved through all the vicissitudes of the past year, and that we are today sound in limb and mind and able to enter upon the discharge of those grave and solemn duties imposed upon us by law.

It is also a source of gratification to us, that we find Your Excellency in the enjoyment of health and surrounded by the most cheering prospects, of a grand and prosperous future, in the new position, which by operation of law, you are called upon to fill.

In keeping with a time-honored custom of this Tribunal, we are here, sir, to pay you officially, our respects and to pledge you the warm, unflinching support and earnest co-opperation of this branch of the Government, in every wise and legitimate measure of Your Excellency's administration.

We wish here to assure Your Excellency, that we highly appreciate the patriotism which influenced you to accept the high office you now fill, as the first citizen of your country, under circumstances so unique in the history of this Republic-Circumstances, which have convulsed and revolutionized nations far greater than this, and with centuries of growth and civilization behind them. We take it as indicative of the political genius, skill, patriotism and predisposition of the people of Liberia to good order,--(which, we would remark, is a cogent reputation of the unfounded theory touching the Negro's unfitness for self-government) that the dangerous chasm which lately happened in our national life, was safely bridged, without producing any of those civil catastrophes, which have in the past, over taken other countries, passing through a similar ordeal.

To be the President of the Republic of Liberia; to direct the destinies of the people, whom ROBERTS, BENSON, and others ruled and covered with renown; to see that no evil befall this sacred heritage bequeathed unto us by the immortal fathers--a heritage made dear to us by their toils and their blood,--this is no light task. He must study the welfare of the whole common-wealth without respect to rank or condition. He must thoroughly recognize his responsibility to the people whom he would successfully serve and seek to discharge that responsibility in every wise and legitimate way. He must place himself in touch of leading and popular thoughts and march to the music of a brilliant future.

The people in their majesty, through the operation of laws made by their lawful representatives, having selected you to be the standard-bearer of this nation, we believe, that the act has the approval of God; and that relying upon the wisdom and power of Him who rules

the unverse, you shall not only succeed in keeping in tact all that has been committed to your trust, but that you will be instrumental in leading forth this Republic to greater glory and brighter renown.

We believe, sir, that the country can rely with safety and composure, upon your broad wisdom, sound, statesmanlike judgment and unflinching devotion to duty;--already demonstrated by a long and brilliant career in the service of your country, to guard with vigil watchfulness the rights and liberties of this people; to represent their claims before the cabinets of the civilized world; to promote the happiness,.peace and prosperity of both citizen and foreigner and to maintain for us, that civil recognition and relgious freedom, which the sleeping SIres of this rising Republic, laboured, bled and died to secure to us and to our posterity.

On behalf of the JUDICIARY of the Republic of Liberia, we congratulate Your Excellency, and we wish you a long and a useful life, good health and signal prosperity. We trust, sir, that the happy relatious which have always existed between the Executive and Judiciary Branches of the Government may continue uninterrupted for all future.
The Liberia Recorder, Monrovia, Thursday, Feb. 28, 1901.
The Close of our third Year.
To-day marks the completion of our third year in the field of Liberian journalism, which after all said and done, is a most trying and difficult one.

Many of our readers, no doubt will be anxious to know whether this issue may not be regarded as the last toll of our death knell declaring the curtain dropt over us, and placing them under the painful necessity of tracing our vestiges along a beaten track, where their last traces may have been obliterated, and their final sounds long hushed in the distant air. To this we answer, no. This issue leaves us a living entity in the field of journalism.
The duty of a public journalist especially in a community like ours is quite a thankless one.

During this short period of our existence we have been called upon to steer into and encounter fruitful sources of temptation and alluring tendencies,-shoals and sand banks to which a journal managed and controled by young and in experienced men must be exposed, and upon which many older and more experienced journalists have too often become stranded and floundered, thereby failing to be any longer a faithful exponent of public opinion or a true fidei defensor of the constitutional rights and privileges of the people.
Whether we have avoided these shoals and sand banks is a question which we leave entirely with our readers to decide.

As journalists we are aware that we have not pleased all parties, nor aided out all nations, whether they be political, social, religious, racial or otherwise, and that amidst well defined policies many to whose personal wishes we did not pander found room to impute base and unworthy motives.
During this our journalistic year which is now at its close, our working expenses have been a little increased and our returns though
far from being as we should have wished them, have on the whole been satisfactory.

In a Leader of our issue of Oct. 12, 1899, we said, "There are a good many readers of the RECORDER who have got into the shameful habit of going about borrowing the paper from those who had t satisfy the Editor before they could get them to read."

This practice if discouraged by our subscribers would materially assist us, because by such discouragement we shall have the opportunity of adding many more names to our list of our subscribers at the commencement of our fourth volume from the ranks of those who read but do not subscribe.

In closing this our third volume we have to express to our subscribers, literary contributors, both at home and abroad, and to all who have directly or indirectly aided us heartfelt thanks and gratitude and humbly request their continued support and encouragement during the ensuing year.

We also record our appreciations of the good feelings and amicable relations which have existed between our local contemporaries, the Baptist Monitor, the Cape Palmas Reporter, the New Africa and ourselves--feelings and relations which cannot but have a salutary effect up on journalism in Liberia. Each journal furnishing materials, in its own way, and instilling principles on which to build up a strong national fabric with a healthy public opinion which till now may be considered as in its embryo.

As our next volume will be opened by a new Editor we cannot outline a policy which will be pursued during the ensuing year, but we are sure, however, that schemes will be developed which will encourage a greater interest in the LIBERIA RECORDER to such an extent that in every house where there is an intelligent reader a copy of this paper will find and enterance.
Our collector will wait on our local subscribers for the renewal of their subscriptions and we trust that he will be pleasantly received and his requests be attended to.
Not easy for a President.

In the space of a short article it would be impossible to enumerate the many grave responsibilities resting upon the President, all of which require extraordinary ability. Consider his legislative functions only. He is required to approve every law passed by the Legislature, or to return it without his signature--but that seldom occurs.

The President, generally, has fixed and intelligent ideas on all subjects of legislation, and either approves or vetoes. As an executive officer, he has to administer every department of the Government; to conduct our foreign relations; to carry on war and to conserve peace; to collect and discharge the revenues; to supervise the administration of Justice; to carry on the mail service, both domestic and foreign; to execute the laws relating to the Aboriginees, public lands, mines patents, and an infinite variety of other subjects; to govern the Interior; and to make treaties. In the performance of the last named duty, he is guided by the advice and consent of the Senate.
Waiving all the thoughts of these numerous and onerous executive functions, which, in themselves call for superior ability, he must, as above stated, devote much time and ability to legislation.
The veto power was placed in his hand as a great perogative to insure the independence of the Executive. By it alone can the executive

office itself and the rights of the people be protected from encroachments upon the part of the legislature and judicial branches of the government. It is a very great power, and, by most of the PResidents, has been very sparingly used; yet, without its sagacious and intelligent exercise form of government would be a sad failure. This signal prerogative on the part of the PResident calls for very great ability and discretion. The power of the veto cannot be entrusted to an inferior, ignorant or capricious man, nor to one who has not carefully studied the history and government of the country at large.
Therefore in our selections of candidates for the Presidency and Vice our leaders should have an eyesingle in these directions.
xThe Manoah River Question.x

There is a matter of vital importance in connection with our relations with Great Britain, which we would like to call the Executive Government's immediate attention to, with the view of their opening correspondence with His Majesty's Government relative to the settlement thereof; provided if such steps have not already been taken. We refer to the propriety of allowing the citizens of the Republic equal right to the free navigation of the Manoh River; which right is at present denied, based upon the second article of the Convention concluded between Great Britain and Liberia at Freetown, Sierra Leone, on the eleventh day of November A. D. 1885, by Sir Samuel Rowe, K.C.M.G., Governor and Commander-in-chief of Sierra Leone and H. B. M.'s Consul for Liberia, representing Great Britain, and the Honorables Henry W. Grimes and Benjamin Anderson in behalf of the PResident of the Republic of Liberia, which article reads as follows:

"The line marking the North Western boundary of the Republic of Liberia shall commence at the point on the sea coast at which at low water, the line of the South Western or left bank of the Manoh River intersects the general line of the sea coast and shall be continued along the line marked by low water on the South Western or left bank of the Manoh River until such line or such line prolonged in a North Easterly direction intersects the line or the prolongation of the line marking the north eastern or inland boundary of the territories of the Republic, within Liberian Territory the Town or Bopora and such other towns as shall be hereafter acknowledged to have belonged to the Republic at the time of signing of this Convention."

From the above article it is easily seen that instead of the Manoh River itself marking the North Western boundary of this Republic it is the left bank of said River at low water which intersects the general line of the sea coast.
Now, article third which describes Great Britain's boundary reads also as follows.

"The President of the Republic of Liberia hereby recognizes the recent acquisition by Her Majesty's Government of certain portions of territory which makes the South Eastern boundary of Her Majesty's possessions in this portion of the line of the north western boundary of the Republic of Liberia as described in article II, which commences at the point on the sea coast at which at low water the line of the South Western or left bank of the Mannoh River intersects the general line of the sea coast and which terminates at the point on the line of the said North Western boundary line nearest to the town of Ngaringa situated on the right bank of the Manoh River."

It is quite obvious that this article concedes to Great Britain the entire river, which if had been wonded thus, "The President of the Republic of Liberia hereby recognizes the recent acquisition by Her Majesty's Government of certain portions of territory which mark the South Eastern boundary of Her Majesty's posessions in this portion of West Africa the boundary of which commences at the point on the sea coast at which at low water the line of the South Eastern or right bank of the Manoh River intersects the general line of the sea coast" etc. etc., the River, then not being included within the territorial limits of either government its navigation would have unquestionably been free and opened to the subjects and citizens of both governments, as it is a well settled principle of International Law, that the boundary which divides two seperate states is neutral ground and is accessable as a common highway between the citizens of both states.

There is no concealing of the fact that the failure on the part of the Special Commissioners of the Government to obtain from the British Government reciprocal rights for the use of the Manoh River was a serious oversight and omission; the effects of which largely hamper and retard the commercial intersts of the Republic.

The greater portion of the trade in that particular section of the country is on our side of the river a great distance up, and our merchants at Cape Mount not being allowed the right of navigation on said river can only get their goods and produce to and fro over-land with the assistance of carriers; which means to them an enormous outlay of money and a most unprofitable business, besides a great waste of time; whereas the English merchant who has the free use of the river can easily convey to and from said point 10 and 20 tons of cargo in a less time and at less expense, by means of a boat or vessel, than the Liberian merchant, who would have to employ not less than 500 to 1000 carriers to convey the same quantity of goods to said point.

Just a month ago a Liberian trader by the name of Hoff was seized by the English authorities on the other side of the River for attempting to navigate said River for the purpose of trade, but has since been released, as we are informe,d under a strong reprimand. We are however of the opinion that it si not the intention of Great Britain to knowlingly take any undrue advantage of this Republic directly or indirectly, and the attitude assumed by the British Government towards Liberia in all matters pertaining to her interests and welfare, heretofore, points in this direction.
